caption.p: Summary of literature referencing the distribution of Speyeria diana (adapted from Wells and Tonkyn 2014).

tr.td: holotype; male described by Pieter Cramer
first record from Indiana, most northern record
first description of female, took over 30 specimens
populations are ample along Blue Ridge
West Virginia, Georgia, Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas
very common along the French Broad River
W. Virginia to Georgia, Southern Ohio to Illinois, Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas
single worn male, northernmost record in OH
Argynnis diana is described as the handsomest insect found in the United States
Semnopsyche diana; an inhabitant of hilly country of the south, 38th parallel of latitude, taken as far west as Missouri and “Arkansaw”
description of Argynnis diana wing spot pattern
female specimen from northern Danville, IL
Diana specimens from southern Illinois are larger than those further east
in two Virginias and Carolinas, northern Georgia, Tennessee, Kentucky, occasionally in southern Ohio and Indiana, and in Missouri and Arkansas; the most magnificent and splendid species of the genus
northern limit of S. diana in Illinois
pair captured in copula, very early female
habitat is West Virginia to Georgia, southern Ohio to Illinois, Tennessee, and Arkansas
Asheville, Brevard, North Carolina, Caesar’s Head, South Carolina, Montgomery, Washington and Giles Counties, Virginia
The Virginias and Carolinas, northern GA Tennessee, Kentucky, occasionally in southern OH, Indiana, and in Missouri and Arkansas
ranges from Bath County, Virginia to FL east almost to tidewater, and west to Illinois and Arkansas
Bath, Alleghany, Giles, Bland, Dickenson, Smyth, Patrick, Montgomery & Washington Counties
Pocahontas County, west to Kanawha and Lincoln Counties; abundant in Jefferson NF (Monroe County), Babcock State Park (Fayette County), and Fork Creek Wildlife Management Area (Boone County)
southern. Ohio and West Virginia, through the Appalachian mountains into Georgia and South Carolina, most abundant in mountains south of Great Smoky Mountains National Park
author collects hundreds of specimens from North Carolina mountains; gone from Indiana and Ohio
in large numbers along roadsides; Chiefly in mountains and piedmont, W. Virginia s. to Georgia, w. to southern Ohio, Indiana, Missouri, and Arkansas
identification of an unknown S. diana larva
summarizes historic reports from White, Union, Fannin, Habersham, Rabun Counties
species is scarce in Kentucky and West
field-captured and lab-reared S. diana gynandromorphs described in detail
has decreased its range because of forest loss, common in the Great Smoky Mountains
extirpated from Virginia Piedmont and coast
occurs in mountains and piedmont of West Virginia south to Georgia, west to southern Ohio, Indiana, Missouri, and Arkansas
males preferred nectar over horse manure
central Appalachians west to Ozarks, formerly Atlantic coastal plain of Va., NC, and Ohio River Valley, rich forested valleys
Gynandromorph specimen found in n. GA
ranges from Virginia and W. Virginia south to northern Georgia and Alabama. A small population persists in Ozark Mountains of Arkansas and Missouri
formerly throughout Ohio River Valley and southeastern Virginia and northwest N.C
locally common in mountain colonies, s. W. Virginia to n. GA; also e. AL/KY, Ozarks

core of species distribution is in the southern Appalachians from central Virgina and W. VA through the mountains to northern Georgia and Alabama. Also in Ozarks of Missouri, Arkansas, and eastern Oklahoma
lots of aggregating females flying late
uncommon to locally common in colonies Scattered throughout the Interior Highlands Coastal Plain
at least four males visiting flowering sourwood
description of Mount Magazine State Park
